thread.title: Rain in Southern California triggers flood advisory, concerns of mud flows in foothills
thread.title_full: Rain in Southern California triggers flood advisory, concerns of mud flows in foothills

author: Joseph Serna
title: Rain in Southern California triggers flood advisory, concerns of mud flows in foothills

organizations.name: los angeles times dale ball of la canada

text:
Rain in Southern California triggers flood advisory, concerns of mud flows in foothills Rain Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times Dale Ball of La Canada has rain gear for herself and her dogs while walking past Devil's Gate Dam toward Hahamongna Watershed Park in Pasadena on Jan. 23. Dale Ball of La Canada has rain gear for herself and her dogs while walking past Devil's Gate Dam toward Hahamongna Watershed Park in Pasadena on Jan. 23. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times) Joseph Serna meteorologist Dave Bruno, but a second spell is expected overnight into early Tuesday.
Even though the rainfall hasn’t been heavy compared with a series of atmospheric rivers that slammed California in January, it has sparked some concerns about overwhelming burn-scarred hillsides in the San Gabriel Valley. 
The city of Duarte issued a yellow alert Sunday night for residents in the impact area around last year’s Fish fire, limiting where residents could park their vehicles and place their trash cans. 
The National Weather Service issued a flood advisory for Ventura County through 8:30 a.m., warning that water could pond on roads, highways and other low lying areas. 
Outside of those issues, the rain is more good news for Southern California, which remains mired in drought but has seen remarkable gains thanks to the wettest winter it’s had in years. 
“It’s a very beneficial type of rain. With any luck it doesn’t get any heavier,” Bruno said. 
There is enough rain to soak into the ground, helping to replenish soil moisture sapped from years of drought, but not too much as to overwhelm local watersheds, Bruno said. 
Late night cloud cover will also keep temperatures warmer in the evening Monday, with temperatures hovering around 50 degrees, he said. 
Another storm is expected to move into Southern California on Thursday night, but most of the rain will be centered in Santa Barbara and Ventura counties, Bruno said. 
California is on pace for its wettest year in recent memory. The storms have alleviated drought conditions for most of Northern California and made a significant dent in the southern half. Caption 90 seconds: 4 stories you can't miss

Neil M. Gorsuch, a highly regarded conservative jurist best known for upholding religious liberty rights in the legal battles over Obamacare, is President Trump's Supreme Court nominee.
